metadata.dataset: Illinois Antiquity & Places of the Past (sites list)
metadata.notes: Structured from guidebook pages; fields may include seasonal hours and may change.

sites.name: Piasa Bird Memorial
sites.address: Ill. Rte. 100 (3 miles north of Alton)
sites.description: In 1673, Marquette and Jolliet observed two monsters painted on the limestone bluffs overlooking the Mississippi River; the current image is reconstructed from more recent lore.

sites.name: Lewis and Clark State Historic Site
sites.hours: May–Labor Day: Mon–Sun 9AM–5PM; Labor Day–Apr: Wed–Sun 9AM–5PM
sites.description: Lewis and Clark established a winter camp in December 1803 near Hartford prior to starting their journey westward; gallery exhibits include a 55-foot full-scale replica of their keel boat.

sites.name: South Roxana Mounds
sites.description: Two mounds that may date to the Middle to Late Woodland period are visible within the park.

sites.name: Madison County Historical Museum
sites.description: Exhibits in a restored 1836 home include Native American and pioneer artifacts.

sites.name: Horseshoe Lake State Park
sites.description: A nearly 3,000-acre park area that includes the Horseshoe Lake platform mound dating to the Mississippian period (AD 1000–1200).

sites.name: Cahokia Courthouse
sites.description: Originally constructed by the French about 1740; later served as a center of political activity in the Illinois Country. WPA excavations in the 1930s are included in the courthouse exhibits.

sites.name: Cahokia Mounds State Historic Site & Interpretive Center
sites.hours: May–Oct: Daily 9AM–5PM; Nov–Dec & Feb–Apr: Wed–Sun 9AM–5PM; Jan: Wed–Sun 9AM–4PM; Grounds: 8AM–dusk
sites.description: Preserves about 2,200 acres of the largest pre-contact American Indian community north of Mexico; at its peak (around AD 1050–1150) the community covered nearly 6 square miles, included about 120 mounds, and may have had a population of 10,000–20,000.

sites.name: Emerald Mound
sites.address: Emerald Mound Road (from Lebanon via IL Rte 4)
sites.description: Owned by the State of Illinois; the largest of the three remaining Mississippian mounds in this group is a large flat-topped pyramid, about 20 feet high.
sites.notes: Directions on brochure: From Lebanon take IL Rte 4 north to Emerald Mound Rd (turn east); mound is south. A driving loop uses Emerald Mound Grange Rd south, then Midgley–Neiss Rd west back to IL Rte 4.

sites.name: Fort de Chartres State Historic Site
sites.notes: Brochure also mentions Feitman Museum (king’s storehouse) and lists an additional contact number 618-826-2667.

sites.name: Modoc Rock Shelter
sites.address: County Rte. 7 (2 miles SE of Prairie du Rocher)
sites.description: Listed on the National Register of Historic Places and a National Historic Landmark. The sandstone bluff at Modoc Rock Shelter provided shelter for Native American groups beginning shortly after the Ice Age, continuing for almost 8,000 years.

sites.name: Fort Kaskaskia State Historic Site
sites.description: The 200-acre bluff-top park includes the remnants of a French earthen-work and timber fortification constructed in the mid-1700s.

sites.name: Piney Creek Ravine State Natural Area
sites.description: Contains the largest body of prehistoric rock art in Illinois, with almost 200 designs believed to date to the Late Woodland (AD 500–1000) and Mississippian (AD 1000–1550) periods.

sites.name: Carlyle Lake Visitor Center
sites.address: US 50 (50 miles east of St. Louis, MO)
sites.hours: Apr–end of May & Sep: Sat–Sun 10AM–6PM; end of May–early Sep: Daily 10AM–6PM
sites.description: Located at the southern end of the 26,000-acre lake; exhibits on construction of the lake, natural history, and a display about area archaeology.

sites.name: General John A. Logan Museum
sites.description: Located in the Christopher C. Bullar house; archaeological collections from a decade of excavations from the original Logan home are on display.

sites.name: Giant City State Park
sites.description: Giant City Stone Fort was constructed during the Late Woodland period (about 1,400–1,200 years ago); interpretive signs can be found on hiking trails.

sites.name: The Pounds Site
sites.address: Rim Rock National Recreation Trail (5 miles east of Garden of the Gods on Karbers Ridge Blacktop)

sites.name: Kaolin Pond
sites.description: Archaeological site managed by the USDA Forest Service; location of a mid-19th-century kaolin clay mine and village.

sites.name: Union County Museum
sites.description: Exhibits include American Indian artifacts from private collections from sites in Union County and southern Illinois; brochure also notes 19th-century pottery vessels from the Kirkpatrick family and Anna Pottery.

sites.name: Millstone Bluff Archaeological Area
sites.description: A unique topographical feature rising 320 feet above surrounding terrain; includes an unpaved prehistoric Mississippian village, stone box cemetery, and a rock art site within the Shawnee National Forest.

sites.name: Thebes Court House
sites.description: The 1845 courthouse is an impressive stone building overlooking the Mississippi River; it has a limited collection of prehistoric artifacts in the basement.

sites.name: Fort Massac State Park
sites.description: Visitor center contains both ancient Native American artifacts and artifacts recovered from Fort Massac during 1939–42, 1966, and 1970 excavations.

sites.name: Kincaid Mounds
sites.description: From an interpretive area and platform, visitors can view mounds preserved at this Middle Mississippian period fortified village and mound site (roughly AD 900–1500).

sites.name: Customs House Museum
sites.description: The Federal Customs House is listed on the National Register of Historic Places; it is a three-story limestone building with collections that include prehistoric Native American artifacts.

sites.name: Ballard Nature Center
sites.hours: Tue–Fri 8AM–4PM; Sat noon–4PM; summer also open Mon & Sun
sites.description: Six miles of trails provide access to 210 acres of woodland, tallgrass prairie, and wetlands; Nature Center displays include a collection of projectile points donated by long-time collector John William Warner.

sites.name: Teutopolis Monastery Museum
sites.description: Within the museum are books and artifacts related to Franciscan Friars during their novitiate year; one room includes displays related to local history, including some Native American material.

sites.name: Hutson Memorial Village Museum
sites.address: Outer South Rose Street (1.5 miles south of Hutsonville)
sites.description: Museum includes five restored/recreated pioneer cabins, a general store and barbershop, a barn, working outhouse, family cabin, log barn, and log church (recreation details continue in brochure).

sites.name: Newton Public Library District
sites.description: Displays include some Native American artifacts.

sites.name: Crawford County Historical Museum
sites.description: Located in the former Schmidt Clinic building; extensive displays of regional Wabash River valley pre-contact Native American sites and pioneer-era sites collected over several decades of archaeological investigations.

sites.name: Fife Opera House
sites.hours: Open for special events & by appointment
sites.description: Display of Palestine-area artifacts (line in brochure is truncated after 'Roy Mor-').

sites.name: Olney Carnegie Library / Carnegie Building Museum
sites.description: Library houses many local artifacts, including Native American artifacts.

sites.name: White County Historical Society (I. L. Haas State Museum)
sites.description: Along with tools, photographs, and vintage clothing, the museum has hanging tools of Phil Hanna ('the hangman'); exhibits also include Native American artifacts.
